Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Deformation-induced Hydration of Peridotite Mylonites in Nature and Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Studies of oceanic fault zones have shown that fluid circulation may drive weakening and seismic failure in the shallow brittle part of these faults. It is generally assumed that fluid circulation ends when rocks transition from brittle failure (fault) to plastic flow (mylonite). However, recent analysis of oceanic peridotite mylonites has revealed the ubiquitous presence of hydrous mineral phases. This project assesses the degree to which water circulates though the brittle-ductile transition in oceanic fault zones, where fracture propagation during seismic events can send water downward into mylonite zones. In this project, peridotite mylonites are analyzed from shear zones in two complementary settings, the St. Paul?s Rocks on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge and the New Caledonia ophiolite. Methods used in this research include fieldwork, microstructural analysis, stable isotope measurements, and mineral thermometry. In addition, laboratory rock deformation experiments are used to investigate the behavior of fluid inclusions during deformation, the chemical environment in which water reacts to form hydrous minerals, and the influence these hydrous phases have in weakening mantle rocks and therefore localizing deformation.

Plate tectonics cycles water from the hydrosphere to the deep mantle. Subducted oceanic plates drive water to several hundred kilometers depth, and volcanism brings it back to the Earth?s surface. This research focuses on how water is incorporated into rocks beneath the ocean floor at mid-ocean ridges, where extension and transform faulting combine with heating from shallow magma to drive seawater circulation. Faulting creates pathways for water flow: during a seismic cycle, fractures propagate to the deeper part of fault zones, allowing water to penetrate the region where rocks normally deform plastically. These fractures heal over time and the fluids are trapped as numerous fluid inclusions. This project investigates the fate of these fluid inclusions during long-term deformation and chemical reaction with mantle rocks to form hydrous minerals, which act as capsules of water-rich material. When the plate eventually dives into a subduction zone, this water will be available for global circulation. Results of this research are relevant to disciplines that are concerned with the role of water in Earth processes, including seismology, petrology and geochemistry, tectonics, and geodynamics. The proposed study would advance desired societal outcomes through: 1) full participation of women in STEM; 2) development of a competitive STEM workforce through training of graduate students and in-reach efforts to undergraduate students; and 3) increased international partnerships through collaboration with New Caledonian geologists and public outreach to New Caledonian communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The ocean floor is underlain by tectonic plates that represent the most dynamic layers of the planet. Oceanic plates form about two thirds of Earth’s solid outer layer and are completely recycled on timescales of less than two hundred million years. During their existence in the near surface oceanic plates diverge at mid-ocean ridges and are driven down into the deep mantle at subduction zones. Mid-ocean ridges are segmented by transform faults where much of the oceanic seismic activity is concentrated. Oceanic transform faults are poorly known; they are reachable by submersible for direct observation and sampling, and their activity is monitored by seismological and other geophysical techniques.  Another way to explore transform faults is to study them in ophiolites. Ophiolites are sheets of oceanic lithosphere that emerged from the deep sea when a buoyant continent was driven beneath an oceanic plate at a convergent plate margin.

This project focuses on one of the largest ophiolites in the world that is exposed on the island of New Caledonia in the western Pacific region. The New Caledonia ophiolite contains a “fossil” transform fault (paleotransform) that was active around 60-50 million years ago and is now available for direct observation and sampling. A large collection of rocks sampled in the New Caledonia paleotransform facilitates the study of the interaction between shearing and hydration. Some samples represent brittle deformation where mantle rocks are transformed into serpentinite during hydration at relatively low temperature. Other samples provide information on deeper, high-temperature deformation processes. This on-land geologic approach allows reconstruction of a transform system from the level where faults generate earthquakes to the ductile layer beneath. Critically, the project focuses on understanding how water circulates in oceanic transforms and how fluid flow interacts with deformation from shallow and cool to deep and hot levels of a transform system.

The project also includes experimental deformation of mantle rocks in order to study the conditions that allow seawater to penetrate and remain into the oceanic lithosphere during transform faulting. This work includes: (1) crack-cook experiments where cracking simulates transient seismic events that are allowing water to infiltrate mantle rocks, and annealing at high temperature that redistributes fluid inclusions at grain boundaries; and (2) high-temperature shearing experiments performed in torsion in the laboratory in order to achieve large displacements, where mantle rocks are deformed in the presence of water.

 Results from observation and analysis of natural rocks from the New Caledonia paleotransform and results from laboratory experiments are complementary and point to common fundamental processes. Findings from this project suggest that seismogenic activity on transform faults results in transient high stress events in the deeper ductile part of the system. At shallow levels, brittle deformation and coupled hydration of mantle is accompanied by serpentinization, and because serpentinite is a weak rock, localization of slip is enhanced and a stable network of faults is generated. The transient propagation of fractures from the brittle to the ductile lithosphere allows fluids to penetrate the deeper lithosphere. The fluid is preserved as fluid inclusions during healing of minerals, and is redistributed toward mineral grain boundaries during annealing if the rock does not deform. If the rock actively deforms, the fluid inclusions self-organize along bands of high permeability, suggesting that fluid flow can occur within the ductile region of transform faults. These results are illuminated by both natural samples, where hydrous minerals such as amphibole are observed in high-temperature ductilely deformed rocks, and experimental samples where fluid is shown to permeate samples during deformation.

This project offers insight into the mechanisms of hydration of the oceanic lithosphere, and therefore participates in understanding the thermomechanical and hydrothermal behaviors of transform faults. In addition, results demonstrate that transform faults may be quite “hydrous”, with implications for a possible source of hydration of the deep mantle as oceanic lithosphere is ultimately subducted.

 

Broader impacts

This project has included early career scientists (Matthew Carter, Anette von der Handt, Vasilis Chatzaras, and Andrea Biedermann) while expanding the project into experimental, analytical, and field-based directions. Synthesis of results involves collaboration among these early career scientists, the project PIs, and the collaborative team led by Prof. Jessica Warren (U Delaware) who has concentrated on dredged ocean material and rocks collected from active transform systems.

Broader impacts also include scientific and cultural exchange with tribal communities in New Caledonia, particularly in Ouassé and Poum. This study has resulted in the development of a part of the summer course offered by the Institute of Rock Magnetism at the University of Minnesota. Summer course students analyzed the magnetic properties of New Caledonia peridotites with the goal of determining susceptibility anisotropy. Students reflected on their interpretations of deformation and serpentinization processes through the examination of thin sections in comparison to their magnetic measurements.
